content: The "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" allows for a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under SEC. 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" provides a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit is based on the amount paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year for qualified employee health insurance expenses, with the applicable percentage determined based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees. The "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" provides a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit percentage is determined based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees, with a specific formula used if the rate exceeds $10,000. The applicable percentage for the small business employee health insurance credit is calculated based on the number of qualified employees and the amount by which the average annual rate of wages exceeds $10,000. If the employer has not more than 50 qualified employees with wages not exceeding $30,000, the applicable percentage is at least 5 percent. The limit on qualified employee health insurance expenses under subsection (a) is $2,000 for self-only coverage and $5,000 for family coverage. If coverage is for only part of the year, the limit is prorated. Special rules and definitions apply for determining employment. Special rules and definitions apply for determining employment under this section. An employer is considered as described in subsection (b) if they employed an average number of employees as specified in the subsection during the 2 preceding calendar years, with considerations for new employers. The term 'qualified employee health insurance expenses' refers to amounts paid by an employer for health insurance coverage provided to at least 50% of qualified employees, excluding amounts paid under salary reduction arrangements. The term 'qualified employee health insurance expenses' excludes amounts paid under salary reduction arrangements for health insurance coverage. A qualified employee is defined as an employee who works more than 30 hours per week for the employer and is not eligible for subsidized health plans. A qualified employee for health insurance expenses is someone who is eligible for subsidized health plans, entitled to benefits under title XVIII of the Social Security Act, a participant in programs under title XIX or XXI of the Act, or eligible for benefits under specific chapters of the United States Code. The term 'employee' excludes certain individuals but includes leased employees. 'Wages' is defined as per section 3121(a). The text discusses the definition of 'wages' and rules applicable to certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code regarding employee health insurance expenses and business credits.
